A Bit About Me...

Hello, my name is Borislav. I currently work as a System Administrator, while always looking to take on some freelance web development. Thank you for taking the time to look at my website to see a sample of my work.

Here are some of the technologies I use:

  • HTML5, CSS, JavaScript ES6
  • SASS, JSX, jQuery
  • Bootstrap, MaterializeCSS
  • React, Vue
  • Firebase, SQL, MongoDB
  • NodeJS, Express
  • CorelDRAW, Affinity Photo

I graduated from the Technical University of Plovdiv as an engineer in Computer Systems and Technology.

Soon after, I started working as an RTL Verification specialist using SystemVerilog and UVM. That position helped me further my knowledge in object oriented programming, use of standardized methodologies, version control and automated bugtesting.

Eventually I moved into System Administration, which helped me improve my knowledge in virtualization, networking, computer automation and working with databases. Now, I seek to expand my knowledge into the vast realm of full stack Web Development.

Birestroika Pub

React Funds Management App

This is an application build for my own personal use, but it can be used by everyone. Once a user has registered, they can input transactions and keep track of their funds. The App is designed to be mobile friendly, where a user can use it easily on the go.


This app features all four CRUD (Create, read, update and delete) functions. It features a fully functional login system, with authorisation and route protection. It is build with React and uses Firebase as a database. Styling is done with bootstrap. It is hosted on firebase (the URL kinti.b-raychev.com redirects to https://reactfundsmanager.
firebaseapp.com/ )

When not authorized, only the registration and login forms are accessible and all attempts at accessing other features via the URL, redirect to the Login page. Feel free to register or login in if you already have an account. You can also use the account test@test.com with password test1234 for example pre-entered transactions.

Each transaction is tied to a user's ID. Users can create, edit or delete a transaction at any time, but cannot access transactions of other users.

New transactions can be added by using the "New" button in the home page. The "entry" field is used as a name for the transaction, "category" is for sorting and statistics purposes (WIP), "details" is used for a more detailed description of the transaction. "Value" only accepts positive or negative numbers, where if a transaction is negative (has - in front of it) it is added as an expense, otherwise it's added as a profit.

    Planned Features:
  • Owed feature
  • Filters & Pagination
  • Settings with a new collection (table) tied to user IDs
  • Statistics
  • Data Encryption
  • Migrating the database from Firebase to MySQL or MongoDB

Check project on github.

React & Vue TODO Apps

Two simple demonstration apps intended to be used as a TODO List or a shopping list. They are essentially the same app made in either React or Vue. They use JSON Placeholder, a fake Online REST API for prototyping, to which they can make create, read and delete requests. As JSON placeholder does not provide an actual database, data does not persist after refreshing the page. Both of the apps are hosted on Netlify.

Online Computer Store

This is a demonstration for an OpenCart based online store. It is hosted on the same platform I am using for this website (a2hosting). The store is available in Bulgarian or English language and currency can be switched between bulgarian leva or euro (use these buttons to do so).

Products are listed by categories and subcategories and can be further refined by filters. A product may be listed in multiple categories. They can be easily be added to cart, compared with other products based on their attributes or added to wishlist.

Management is done through an admin panel, where the owner of the site can control everything. For a better view of all of the features the admin panel and OpenCart give, click here for a demo.

Check out the store.

FreeCodeCamp Projects

Here are some of the projects I have done as part of the FreeCodeCamp certification process:

Simon Says

A memory game based on the game Simon Says. Users are required to remember a sequence of steps, up to 20 levels. Every few levels the speed of the game also increases. The game features a strict mode that resets the progress whenever a mistake is made.

See the code on codepen.

Calculator

Calculator written in Javascript. With this project I did not only want to emulate a physical calculator, but make it so the user is able to do fast, seamless calculations with keyboard inputs.

See the code on codepen.

Pomodoro Clock

A productivity timer app made with JavaScript. The idea is for the user to have a working session followed by a break session. The user can change the length of each session, pause or reset to start over. The sessions duration are remembered in the browser's local storage.

See the code on codepen.

Tic Tac Toe

A Tic Tac Toe game made with JavaScript. The user can select to play as either X and start first, or O to start second.

See the code on codepen.

Twitch Watcher

Another app made with JavaScript, where the user can check if their favorite streamers are currently streaming on twitch. It uses the twitch API. While the app offers a pre-made list of streamers, the user is able to customize it, by removing or adding their own. The settings are stored in the browser's local storage.

See the code on codepen.

React Contact Manager

This is a contact manager app written with React. It uses JSON Placeholder, a fake Online REST API in the place of a database. Data is requested from JSON placeholder. While you can add, edit or delete in it, as there is no database, the data does not persist upon refreshing the page. My funds management app is built as an improvement of this app, featuring a database provided by firebase. This app is hosted on Github Pages.

Check project on github.
